elements.content: Three interesting copper complexes, {[CuI 6CuII 6L1 6(H2O)3(CH3OH)6]·5H2O·3CH3OH} n (2), [CuI 6CuII 6L2 6(H2O)10] n (3), and [Cu3L3 2(CH3OH)4] (4) [H3L1 = 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)ethanoic acid, H3L2 = 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)propionic acid, H3L3 = 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)benzoic acid], have been synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, XPS, elemental analyses, EPR, and IR spectra. Polymer 2 was synthesized by the reaction of single crystals of {[Ln2(H2L1)4(Phen)2(NO3)2]·CH3OH} [Ln = Pr (1a), Nd (1b), or Ho (1c), Phen = 1,10-phenanthroline] with Cu(OAc)2 in aqueous DMF. Compounds 3 and 4 were prepared by Cu(OAc)2 directly reacting with H3L2 or H3L3 in solution, respectively. Complexes 2 and 3 are rare 2D cluster polymers containing unique mixed-valence [CuI 6CuII 6L1 6] or [CuI 6CuII 6L2 6] subunits. Compound 4 is a trinuclear copper(II) complex, in which two triply deprotonated (L3)3– ligands bridge three Cu2+ ions. The theoretical predication of the substituent effect of the three triply deprotonated ligands (L1)3–, (L2)3–, and (L3)3– has been presented. The thermal properties of complexes 2–4 have been determined as well. Also, it is discovered that there exists weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the neighboring Cu(II) ions in 2, 3, or 4, respectively; the best fittings to the experimental magnetic susceptibilities gave J = −1.63 cm–1 and g = 2.14 for 3 and J = −12.06 cm–1, J′ = −0.01 cm–1, and g = 2.21 for 4.

elements.content: Considering the unique structural features and applications of metal clusters in biological systems, in catalysis, and in optical–electronic functional materials, researchers have strong interest in introducing the metal clusters into coordination polymer systems and investigating their intriguing structural versatility and potential applications. There are some coordination polymers bearing copper clusters as connecting nodes, but reports on polymers built by mixed-valence CuICuII clusters are limited. Thus, the rational design of the polymers with mixed-valence CuICuII clusters is still a challenge for chemists.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Considering the unique structural features and applications of metal clusters in biological systems, in catalysis, and in optical-electronic functional materials, researchers have strong interest in introducing the metal clusters into coordination polymer systems and investigating their intriguing structural versatility and potential applications. There are some coordination polymers bearing copper clusters as connecting nodes, but reports on polymers built by mixed-valence CuICuII clusters are limited. Thus, the rational design of the polymers with mixed-valence CuICuII clusters is still a challenge for chemists.

elements.content: On the other hand, it is well-known that the geometry of ligating atoms within a polynucleating ligand, the flexibility of the ligand backbone, and the additional functional groups of the ligands all play important roles in directing the extended structure of the resulting complex. However, it is still difficult to precisely predicate the influence of complicated organic ligands on the final structures of corresponding complexes. To obtain the useful information about coordination abilities of the organic ligands, a quantum chemical calculation method is a useful tool now.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, it is well-known that the geometry of ligating atoms within a polynucleating ligand, the flexibility of the ligand backbone, and the additional functional groups of the ligands all play important roles in directing the extended structure of the resulting complex. However, it is still difficult to precisely predicate the influence of complicated organic ligands on the final structures of corresponding complexes. To obtain the useful information about coordination abilities of the organic ligands, a quantum chemical calculation method is a useful tool now.

elements.content: On the basis of the two considerations above, we choose three similar thiourea-based carboxylate ligands, 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)ethanoic acid (H3L1), 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)propionic acid (H3L2), and 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)benzoic acid (H3L3) (Scheme ) to extend our research. It is well-accepted that CuII can be reduced to CuI by thiourea derivatives. Furthermore, the thiourea derivatives bearing one carbonyl, one thiocarbonyl, one carboxylate, and two NH groups may be completely or partially deprotonated and then show various coordination modes and have abilities to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble various supramolecular structures. Theoretical investigations of ligands H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3 based on quantum chemical calculations will gain further insight into the influence of the coordination abilities.

elements.content: Consequently, two novel 2D cluster coordination polymers, {[CuI 6CuII 6L1 6(H2O)3(CH3OH)6]·5H2O·3CH3OH} n (2) and [CuI 6CuII 6L2 6(H2O)10] n (3), containing unique mixed-valence CuIICuI subunits, and one trinuclear Cu(II) complex, [Cu3L3 2(CH3OH)4] (4) (Scheme ), have been obtained. It is to be pointed out that the polymer 2 was prepared by conversion of a substrate of single crystals to a product of single crystals, which showed an interesting single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation induced by cation exchange, and has been reported in our pervious communication. Polymer 3 and trinuclear complex 4 were prepared by direct solution reaction of thiourea-based carboxylate ligands with Cu(OAc)2. Their thermal, and magnetic properties have been investigated as well.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent-grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. The organic ligands H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3 were prepared according to literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All chemicals were of reagent-grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. The organic ligands H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3 were prepared according to literature procedures.

elements.content: C, H, N, and S microanalyses were carried out on a FLASH EA 1112 analyzer. IR data were recorded on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. TG–DSC measurements were performed by heating the sample from 20 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min–1 in air on a Netzsch STA 409PC differential thermal analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) determination was measured in a PHI5300-type instrument, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was recorded on a JES-FA200 instrument at room temperature. The optimized geometries and NBO charge distributions of the triply deprotonated ligands were given by the Gaussian 03 suite of programs, and all calculations were carried out at the B3LYP/6-311++G (d, p) level of theory. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on a SQUID susceptometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-5) in the temperature range of 2.0–300 K with an applied field of 1000 G. All magnetic data have been corrected for diamagnetism by using Pascal’s constants.

elements.content: A mixture of Ln(NO3)3 and 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) and H3L1 in a solution of methanol and water was put aside at room temperature for 1 week to evaporate slowly. Quality crystals for 1a, 1b, and 1c were obtained, respectively. Details of the synthesis of complexes 1a–c have been described previously.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Ln2(H2L1)4(Phen)2(NO3)2]⋅CH3OH} [Ln = Pr (1a), Nd (1b), or Ho (1c)]

A mixture of Ln(NO3)3 and 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) and H3L1 in a solution of methanol and water was put aside at room temperature for 1 week to evaporate slowly. Quality crystals for 1a, 1b, and 1c were obtained, respectively. Details of the synthesis of complexes 1a-c have been described previously.

elements.content: A solution of Cu(OAc)2 in methanol was added dropwise to a stirred solution of complex 1a (or 1b, or 1c) in DMF/H2O mixture at 90 °C. The resulting solution was stirring for 10 min and filtered after cooling to room temperature. Dark-green single crystals of 2 were obtained by slow evaporation after 2 weeks. Details of the synthesis of complex 2 have been reported previously.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[CuI 6CuII 6L1 6(H2O)3(CH3OH)6]⋅5H2O⋅3CH3OH} n  (2)

A solution of Cu(OAc)2 in methanol was added dropwise to a stirred solution of complex 1a (or 1b, or 1c) in DMF/H2O mixture at 90 °C. The resulting solution was stirring for 10 min and filtered after cooling to room temperature. Dark-green single crystals of 2 were obtained by slow evaporation after 2 weeks. Details of the synthesis of complex 2 have been reported previously.

elements.content: A solution of H3L2 (12.6 mg, 0.05 mmol) in methanol (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of Cu(OAc)2·H2O (19.9 mg, 0.1 mmol) in methanol (3 mL), and then water (1 mL) was added to the mixture. Immediately, a dark green solution was formed, which was left to stand for 3 weeks; dark green block crystals of 3 were obtained. Yield: 67.3%. Anal. Calcd for C66H68N12O28S6Cu12: C, 32.59; H, 2.82; N, 6.91; S, 7.91. Found: C, 32.62; H, 2.34; N, 6.72; S, 7.75. IR (cm–1, KBr): 3385 m, 1584 s, 1521 s, 1450 s, 1378 s, 1213 m, 1157 w, 967 w, 874 w, 754 w, 720 w, 691 w, 562 w, 410 w.

Preparation of [Cu3L3 2(CH3OH)4] (4)

A solution of H3L3 (15.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) in methanol (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of Cu(OAc)2⋅H2O (19.9 mg, 0.1 mmol) in methanol (3 mL), and then water (1 mL) was added to the mixture. elements.content: Crystal data and experimental details for 1a–c and 2 have been reported previously. Crystal data and experimental details for compounds 3 and 4 are contained in Table . Measurements of compounds 3 and 4 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Single crystals of 3 and 4 were selected and mounted on a glass fiber. All data were collected at room temperature using the ω–2θ scan technique and corrected for Lorenz polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

Crystal data and experimental details for 1a-c and 2 have been reported previously. Crystal data and experimental details for compounds 3 and 4 are contained in Table . Measurements of compounds 3 and 4 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å). Single crystals of 3 and 4 were selected and mounted on a glass fiber. All data were collected at room temperature using the ω-2θ scan technique and corrected for Lorenz polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied.

The two structures were solved by direct methods and expanded using the Fourier technique. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were included but not refined. The final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on 10 497 observed reflections and 538 variable parameters for 3 and 3285 observed reflections and 242 variable parameters for 4. All calculations were performed using the SHELX-97 crystallographic software package. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table . CCDC 730776, 730775, 730774, 730777, 760000, and 782390 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1a, 1b, 1c, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms for 1a: #1, –x + 1, –y, –z + 1. For 1b: #1, –x + 1, –y, –z + 1. For 1c: #1, –x + 1, –y, –z + 1. For 3: #1, –x + 1, –y + 1, –z; #2, –x + 1, y + 1/2, –z + 1/2; #3, –x + 1, y – 1/2, –z + 1/2. For 4: #1, y, x, –z.

As is aforementioned in the , the factors governing the reaction and formation of the complexes are complicated. It was found that the position and type of functional groups on the ligand are crucial for the generation of resulting frameworks from the different structures. Furthermore, in order to synthesize the complexes purposefully and predict their possible structures, the optimized geometries and natural bond orbital (NBO) charge distributions of the triply deprotonated ligands, (L1)3–, (L2)3–, and (L3)3–, were calculated by the B3LYP/6-311++G(d, p) level of theory, respectively. The computed results (Scheme ) reveal that the three ligands have two interesting features: (1) The negative NBO charges mainly distribute on the oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur atoms. The NBO charges are successively −0.777, −0.853, and −0.802 for O, −0.638 and −0.564 for N, and −0.584 for S in the ligand (L1)3‑; −0.776, −0.825, and −0.824 for O, −0.638 and −0.574 for N, and −0.577 for S in the ligand (L2)3–; and −0.789, −0.776, and −0.799 for O, −0.635 and −0.579 for N, and −0.472 for S in the ligand (L3)3–. These values indicate that the oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur atoms of the three ligands all have potential abilities of coordination to metal ions. So under appropriate reaction conditions, the three ligands can triply deprotonate and show various coordination modes. This finding can be confirmed by our present experimental results. (2) Compared with the NBO charges of the three ligands, we find that the introduction of a phenyl group into (L3)3– has some effect on the NBO charge distributions of S atom, a slight effect on O atoms, and almost no effect on N atoms. So the coordination ability of S atom in the (L3)3– ligand is reduced remarkably. Also the steric effect of the bulky phenyl unit in (L3)3– is significant. Usually the steric hindrance of the bulky phenyl group may prevent (L3)3– from linking more metal ions, which can be concluded by the result of our experiment. Compounds 2 and 3 are novel 2D cluster polymeric structures, which are built by unique mixed-valence [CuI 6CuII 6L6] subunits. However, compound 4 is a relatively simple trinuclear complex.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

As is aforementioned in the , the factors governing the reaction and formation of the complexes are complicated. It was found that the position and type of functional groups on the ligand are crucial for the generation of resulting frameworks from the different structures. Furthermore, in order to synthesize the complexes purposefully and predict their possible structures, the optimized geometries and natural bond orbital (NBO) charge distributions of the triply deprotonated ligands, (L1)3-, (L2)3-, and (L3)3-, were calculated by the B3LYP/6-311++G(d, p) level of theory, respectively. The computed results (Scheme ) reveal that the three ligands have two interesting features: (1) The negative NBO charges mainly distribute on the oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur atoms. The NBO charges are successively -0.777, -0.853, and -0.802 for O, -0.638 and -0.564 for N, and -0.584 for S in the ligand (L1)3-; -0.776, -0.825, and -0.824 for O, -0.638 and -0.574 for N, and -0.577 for S in the ligand (L2)3-; and -0.789, -0.776, and -0.799 for O, -0.635 and -0.579 for N, and -0.472 for S in the ligand (L3)3-. These values indicate that the oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur atoms of the three ligands all have potential abilities of coordination to metal ions. So under appropriate reaction conditions, the three ligands can triply deprotonate and show various coordination modes. This finding can be confirmed by our present experimental results. (2) Compared with the NBO charges of the three ligands, we find that the introduction of a phenyl group into (L3)3- has some effect on the NBO charge distributions of S atom, a slight effect on O atoms, and almost no effect on N atoms. So the coordination ability of S atom in the (L3)3- ligand is reduced remarkably. Also the steric effect of the bulky phenyl unit in (L3)3- is significant. Usually the steric hindrance of the bulky phenyl group may prevent (L3)3- from linking more metal ions, which can be concluded by the result of our experiment. Compounds 2 and 3 are novel 2D cluster polymeric structures, which are built by unique mixed-valence [CuI 6CuII 6L6] subunits. However, compound 4 is a relatively simple trinuclear complex.

elements.content: In a word, the structures of complexes 2–4 are affected significantly by the three similar thiourea ligands, H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3, which show different lengths and angles and play fundamental roles in the formation of the final products. It is an effective way to modify organic ligands to construct different structural target complexes. It is to be pointed out that 2 was prepared by the reaction of Cu(OAc)2·H2O with 1a (or 1b or 1c) in DMF/H2O solution, whereas crystals of 2 were not yielded by mixing Cu(OAc)2·H2O and H3L1 in DMF/H2O/CH3OH under similar conditions. Neither could the polymer 2 be yielded when solvent (MeCN, DMSO, CH2Cl2) or pH was changed. It is concluded that the use of 1a, 1b, or 1c was required for the preparation of crystalline 2. However, the complexes 3 and 4 were synthesized by mixing directly the Cu(OAc)2·H2O and H3L2 or H3L3 in CH3OH/H2O solution. Unexpectedly, compounds 3 and 4 were prepared through the regular solution method of volatiles by mixing Cu(OAc)2·H2O and ligands in H2O/CH3OH. It is not necessary to use the crystalline dimers 1a–c in the preparation process of 3 and 4, unlike 2. If the solvent was replaced by others, such as H2O/CH3CN, H2O/CH3CH2OH, and H2O/DMF, no crystalline powder can be got. Despite this, the role of lanthanide(III) ions in the construction of polymer 2 is ambiguous. The different preparation methods of 2–4 may be due to the slight structural difference of corresponding ligands. Interestingly, compound 3 is also a rare 2D copper cluster polymer and has similarities in structure with polymer 2 to some extent. However, compound 4 is a trinuclear complex. The reason was discussed in the above part on NBO charge distributions. It is noteworthy that the anion of metal salt may affect the crystal shape of final product. If Cu(OAc)2·H2O is changed to Cu(NO3)2 or CuSO4 in the synthesis of 2, no crystalline product can be generated, which suggests that the anion OAc– plays an important role in the formation of crystalline 2. The similar cases can be found in the syntheses of 3 and 4. As described in the literature, the effect of counteranions on the self-assembly of coordination complexes is complicated. We presumed that the OAc– anion is in favor of the growth of crystalline products of 2–4.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅; the adjacent Pr(III) ions are connected by six bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms of (H2L1)− units, forming a dinuclear complex.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅; the adjacent Pr(III) ions are connected by six bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms of (H2L1)- units, forming a dinuclear complex.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, each Pr(III) ion is nine-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N1, N2) from one Phen unit, two oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from one η2-NO3 – anion, five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4A, O5A, O8A, O4, and O7) from two μ2-η2-(H2L1)− and two μ2-(H2L1)− ligands, forming a distorted tricapped trigonal prism coordination polyhedron. The Pr–O bond lengths range from 2.397(3) to 2.614(3) Å. The two Pr–N bond lengths are 2.662(3) and 2.638(3) Å, respectively. The bond angles around each Pr(III) atom range from 49.11(12)° to 149.13(11)°. In compound 1b, the bond lengths of Nd–O range from 2.385(3) to 2.640(4) Å, and two Nd–N distances are 2.609(5) and 2.654(4) Å respectively. The bond angels around each Nd(III) atom are in the range of 50.0(2)–150.69(15)°. In compound 1c, the bond lengths of Ho–O vary from 2.295(3) to 2.554(3) Å. The two Ho–N distances are 2.527(3) and 2.557(3) Å, respectively. The bond angles of O–Ho–O are in the range of 52.53(8)–149.71(10)° (Table ).

The intradimeric metallic distance of Pr1···Pr1A is 3.9884(16) Å [for 1b, intradimeric metallic distance of Nd1···Nd1A = 4.0031(11) Å; for 1c, intradimeric metallic distance of Ho1···Ho1A = 3.8558(15) Å]. The dihedral angle between the benzene rings of the two (μ2-η2-H2L1)− ligands is 6.5°, and the dihedral angle of the two Phen units is 0.0°. In the solid-state structure, the compounds are packed to each other through weak π...π stacking between the Phen rings (the distance between the two Phen rings being 3.395, 3.428, and 3.401 Å for 1a, 1b, and 1c, respectively) or phenyl rings (the distance between the two phenyl rings being 3.559, 3.573, and 3.582 Å for 1a, 1b, and 1c, respectively), forming a 2D interdigitated sheet in the ab plane (Figure b).

elements.content: In 3, each (L2)3– ligand connects four copper ions through its five coordination sites, behaving as an O-, N-, and S-centered ligand. As shown in Figure a, the complex 3 contains hexanuclear clusters in which six copper(I) centers are bridged by six (L2)3– ligands. The copper(I) ions in central Cu6 units bond to each other with Cu–S bonds, and the Cu–S bond distances vary from 2.284(2) to 2.291(2) Å, which is close to that of the reported copper(I) cluster compound hexanuclear 6-methyl-2-pyridinethiolato (6-mpyt) copper(I) [Cu6(6-mpyt)6]. The [CuI 6S6] units have an imperial crown structure, which was connected through Cu(I) and S atoms. The average distance between two neighboring Cu(I) ions is 2.7206(8) Å, which is similar to that of compound 2 and is close to sum of the van der Waals radii, 2.80 Å, respectively, indicative of the existence of strong Cu···Cu interactions. The CuI–N bond lengths vary from 2.043(6) to 2.074(6) Å, and the bond angles of S–CuI–S lie in the range of 101.05(7)°–117.86(7)°, respectively. The coordination sites of CuII are occupied by one nitrogen atom and four oxygen atoms from (L2)3‑ ligands and water molecules. The addison parameter (τ = 0.115) of Cu4 (τ = 0.115 of Cu5; τ = 0.13 of Cu6) reveals that the geometry around the Cu(II) atom is a slightly distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The CuII–O bond lengths vary from 1.869(7) to 2.666(11) Å and the CuII–N bond lengths fall in the range of 1.909(5)–1.944(6) Å, respectively. Interestingly, the basic structures of the unit are connected through the oxygen atom (O9) of (L2)3‑ ligands to form a 2D layer regularly, which is shown in Figure b.

elements.content: It displays an interesting 2D sheet structure constructed by [CuI 6CuII 6L2 6] subunits and carboxylato linkages. CuI and CuII ions are located in two different coordination environments as those in compound 2. The existence of CuI and CuII ions has been well-demonstrated by the XPS (Figure ) and EPR (, Figure S1) measurements. The XPS spectrum of 3 shows that the evident shoulder peaks of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 at 934.2 and 954.6 eV, respectively, suggesting the presence of CuI in the compound, while satellite peaks at 943.7 and 962.1 eV indicate that the complex may also contain CuII ions. The intense EPR spectral signal is consistent with the existence of CuII in 3. As noted previously, thiourea ligands may reduce CuII to CuI. Evidently, like polymer 2, the thiourea-based ligand [H2L2]− has a reducing role.

elements.content:
X-ray analysis reveals that compound 4 crystallizes in the trigonal P3(2)21 space group and shows an interesting trinuclear structure, [Cu3L3 2(CH3OH)4] (Figure ).

The compound 4 contains three copper(II) atoms, two (L3)3‑ ligands, as well as four coordinated methanol molecules. There are two kinds of crystallographically distinguishable copper ions, Cu1 and Cu2 (or Cu2A). The Cu1 atom sphere has tetrahedral geometry occupied by two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N2A) and two S atoms (S3 and S3A) from two individual (L3)3– ligands. The Cu1–N2 and Cu1–S3 lengths are 1.975(3) and 2.2720(9) Å, respectively. The bond angles around the central Cu1 are in the range of 72.91(8)–157.68(7)°, which largely deviated from the ideal tetrahedral bond angles. As a ligand with multicoordination sites, other one nitrogen atom N1 (or N1A), two oxygen atoms O2 and O3 (O2A and O3A) coordinate to copper atom Cu2 (or Cu2A). The four methanol molecules take part in the coordination to Cu2 or Cu2A atoms. The τ value (0.165) of five-coordinated Cu2 (Cu2A) atom shows that the geometry around the Cu(II) atom is a distorted square-pyramid. The average Cu2–O distance is 2.029 Å. The bond angles around Cu2 vary from 85.67(8)° to 171.47(11)°. The Cu2–N distance is 1.948(3) Å, which can be comparable to Cu1–N distances. Obviously, as shown in the (Figure S2), the EPR spectral signal for Cu(II) ion is intense.

elements.content: We have described that the thiourea ligands show reducing properties, as evident in 2 and 3. Although H3L3 is a thiourea ligand and is closely related to H3L1 and H3L2, the reducing nature of H3L3 is suppressed in 4. This can be explained by comparison of the NBO charge distributions of S atoms for the three ligands [for (L1)3–, −0.584; for (L2)3–, −0.577; For (L3)3–, −0.472]. Obviously, the lower NBO charge distribution of S atom for (L3)3‑ may reduce its electron donor ability.

elements.content: The IR spectra of compounds 2–4 in the region 4000–450 cm–1 are provided in the . The infrared spectra of 2, 3, or 4 obviously differ from that of the relative ligand. The characteristic ν(CO) (carboxylate group) mode of the free ligands H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3 (1700 cm–1) disappeared upon complexation. Other characteristic bands ν(CS) (1213 cm–1 for 2, 1213 cm–1 for 3, 1209 cm–1 for 4) and ν(CO) (carbonyl group) (1653 cm–1 for 2, 1584 cm–1 for 3, 1627 cm–1 for 4) of the free ligands all shift to lower frequency, showing that N, S, and O (carbonyl group) all coordinate to the metal ions. The strong ν(OH) band appears at 3422–3447 cm–1 in the IR spectra of all of the complexes, which proves the existence of coordination or lattice methanol or coordination water in these complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectra, Thermal Analyses, and Magnetic Properties

The IR spectra of compounds 2-4 in the region 4000-450 cm-1 are provided in the . The infrared spectra of 2, 3, or 4 obviously differ from that of the relative ligand. The characteristic ν(CO) (carboxylate group) mode of the free ligands H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3 (1700 cm-1) disappeared upon complexation. Other characteristic bands ν(CS) (1213 cm-1 for 2, 1213 cm-1 for 3, 1209 cm-1 for 4) and ν(CO) (carbonyl group) (1653 cm-1 for 2, 1584 cm-1 for 3, 1627 cm-1 for 4) of the free ligands all shift to lower frequency, showing that N, S, and O (carbonyl group) all coordinate to the metal ions. The strong ν(OH) band appears at 3422-3447 cm-1 in the IR spectra of all of the complexes, which proves the existence of coordination or lattice methanol or coordination water in these complexes.

elements.content:
Compounds 2 and 3 show similar thermal behaviors, but they are different from 4. The TG curves for 2–4 are shown in Figure , and the DSC curves for 2–4 are illustrated in Figure .

There is one small exothermic peak at 195.0 °C, one very strong exothermic peak at 468.2 °C, and one small endothermic peak at 737.9 °C on the DSC curve of polymer 2. TG data show that polymer 2 exhibits an initial weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C and then loses 59.94% of its weight sharply from 200 to 600 °C, corresponding to losses of solvent water molecules, methanol molecules, and the decomposition of some organic ligands. It losing an additional 11.28% from 600 to 723 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of the rest of the ligands. The decomposed reactions end at 723 °C. The final black residues are a mixture of 9CuO and 4.5Cu2S (observed 34.78%, calculated 34.59%).

elements.content: The TG–DSC curves have been obtained under flowing air for a crystalline sample of 4 in the temperature range of 20–800 °C. TG data show that compound 4 first indicates a continuous weight loss of 65.68% from room temperature to 502.5 °C, corresponding to losses of solvent methanol molecules and decomposition of partial ligands. The second weight loss of 7.78% between 718.8 and 791 °C corresponds to loss of the rest of the organic ligands. The black residue is mixture of CuO and Cu2S (observed 26.54%, calculated 26.13%). One small exothermic peak at 187.1 °C and one very strong exothermic peak at 475.4 °C can be observed on the DSC curve of trimer 4. According to the TG behaviors of 2–4 discussed above, it is apparent that the exothermic peaks correspond to the loss of solvent molecules and the decomposition of organic ligands, especially the strong peak around 470 °C. The small endothermic peak at high temperatures of 2–4 may be attributed to the formation of the mass of the final residue.

elements.content: A variable-temperature magnetic study on 2 or 3 was carried out over the temperature range of 2.0–300 K. The variation of the inverse of the magnetic susceptibility, χm –1 and χm T, of 2 and 3 are shown in parts a and b of Figure , respectively. At 300 K, χM T is equal to 0.533 cm3 K mol–1 (for 2) or 0.489 cm3 K mol–1 (for 3), which is larger than the spin only value of uncoupled (S Cu = 1/2, g = 2. 0) copper(II) ions (0.374 cm3 K mol–1). For 2, the thermal evolution of χM –1 obeys the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ), in the temperature range of 285–2.0 K with a Weiss constant, θ, of −5.394 K and a Curie constant, C M, of 0.529 cm3 K mol–1. On lowering the temperature, the χM T value decreases smoothly, and below 35 K it decreases abruptly to a minimum of 0.352 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. For 3, the thermal evolution of χM –1 obeys the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ), in the whole temperature range with a Weiss constant, θ, of −5.451 K and Curie constant, C M, of 0.486 cm3 K mol–1. As the temperature is lowered, the χM T value steadily decreases to 0.424 cm3 K mol–1 at 30 K. After that, it sharply decreases to 0.211 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. Such χM T vs T curves and the negative θ values can be referred to the presence of typical antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between neighboring Cu(II) ions in polymers 2 or 3, respectively.

elements.content: Three lanthanide(III) dimers 1a–c, two rare 2D cluster polymers 2 and 3 with unique mixed-valence [CuI 6CuII 6L6] subunits, and one trinuclear complex 4 have been successfully prepared basing on three similar thiourea-based ligands. Their molecular structures have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, XPS, elemental analyses, EPR, and IR spectra. The results show that the structures of complexes 2–4 are affected significantly by the three thiourea-based ligands, H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3. It is an effective way to modify organic ligands to get different structural target complexes. The introduction of methyl or phenyl group into H3L2 or H3L3 can slightly or largely influence the coordination ability of S atoms of H3L2 or H3L3, respectively. And quantum-chemical calculation method is also a valuable tool to predicate the coordination ability of different organic ligands. By which the NBO charges of the organic ligands can be calculated and show the changes of the coordination ability of potential coordination atoms. elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three lanthanide(III) dimers 1a-c, two rare 2D cluster polymers 2 and 3 with unique mixed-valence [CuI 6CuII 6L6] subunits, and one trinuclear complex 4 have been successfully prepared basing on three similar thiourea-based ligands. Their molecular structures have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, XPS, elemental analyses, EPR, and IR spectra. The results show that the structures of complexes 2-4 are affected significantly by the three thiourea-based ligands, H3L1, H3L2, and H3L3. It is an effective way to modify organic ligands to get different structural target complexes. The introduction of methyl or phenyl group into H3L2 or H3L3 can slightly or largely influence the coordination ability of S atoms of H3L2 or H3L3, respectively. And quantum-chemical calculation method is also a valuable tool to predicate the coordination ability of different organic ligands. By which the NBO charges of the organic ligands can be calculated and show the changes of the coordination ability of potential coordination atoms. Finally, antiferromagnetic coupling between the neighboring Cu(II) ions in 2, 3 or 4, respectively, can be observed and fitted.

cln_elements.content:
Compounds 2 and 3 show similar thermal behaviors, but they are different from 4. The TG curves for 2–4 are shown in Figure , and the DSC curves for 2–4 are illustrated in Figure .

There is one small exothermic peak at 195.0 °C, one very strong exothermic peak at 468.2 °C, and one small endothermic peak at 737.9 °C on the DSC curve of polymer 2. TG data show that polymer 2 exhibits an initial weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C and then loses 59.94% of its weight sharply from 200 to 600 °C, corresponding to losses of solvent water molecules, methanol molecules, and the decomposition of some organic ligands. It losing an additional 11.28% from 600 to 723 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of the rest of the ligands. The decomposed reactions end at 723 °C. The final black residues are a mixture of 9CuO and 4.5Cu2S (observed 34.78%, calculated 34.59%).

For polymer 3, there are two small exothermic peaks at 195.0 and 568.2 °C, one very strong exothermic peak at 475.9 °C, and one small endothermic peak at 751.1 °C on the DSC curve of polymer 3. TG data show that polymer 3 has an initial weight loss of 8.82% from room temperature to 182.5 °C, corresponding to loss of the water molecules, and then it began to decompose with a continuous, sharp weight loss of 41.49% up to 568.2 °C. It loses an additional 13.21% of weight from 568.2 to 751.1 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of the rest of organic ligands. The decomposed reactions end at 751.1 °C. The final black residues are the mixture of 6CuO and 3Cu2S (observed 38.87%, calculated 39.31%).

The TG–DSC curves have been obtained under flowing air for a crystalline sample of 4 in the temperature range of 20–800 °C. TG data show that compound 4 first indicates a continuous weight loss of 65.68% from room temperature to 502.5 °C, corresponding to losses of solvent methanol molecules and decomposition of partial ligands. The second weight loss of 7.78% between 718.8 and 791 °C corresponds to loss of the rest of the organic ligands. The black residue is mixture of CuO and Cu2S (observed 26.54%, calculated 26.13%). One small exothermic peak at 187.1 °C and one very strong exothermic peak at 475.4 °C can be observed on the DSC curve of trimer 4. According to the TG behaviors of 2–4 discussed above, it is apparent that the exothermic peaks correspond to the loss of solvent molecules and the decomposition of organic ligands, especially the strong peak around 470 °C. The small endothermic peak at high temperatures of 2–4 may be attributed to the formation of the mass of the final residue.

Trimer <bold>4</bold>

Variable-temperature magnetic study on 4 is performed over the temperature range of 2.0–300 K. The variation of the inverse of the magnetic susceptibility, χM –1 and χM T, of 4 are shown in Figure c. The thermal evolution of χM –1 obeys Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ) in the temperature range of 279–11 K with Weiss constant, θ, of −18.6 K, the Curie constant, C M, of 1.55 cm3 K mol–1. At 300 K, the χM T value is 1.502 cm3 K mol–1, which is larger than expected for three uncoupled copper(II) ions (1.3 cm3 K mol–1). This value decreases smoothly to 0.405 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The decreases of χM T and negative θ value are attributed to antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) centers in trimer 4.
